Description: Shoulder sherd of East Greek black-figured pottery open vessel, probably krater, with right hand root of horizontal or strirrup handle; much silver mica in clay; interior glazed streaky black; exterior: on left (under handle), black-figure decoration consisting of part of uncertain creature or ornament (possibly part of shield and chin of its carrier, to right) and open rosette with dot in centre; on right of handle, probably part of lion's rump, to right (two curving lines at base of tail); inscription incised beside handle and animal.
Curator's comments: The hand of the graffito is similar to that of another dedication by (a) Phoinix, British Museum 1888,0601.311; that piece would however seem to be rather later in date, though a date c.570 might just accommodate both. The glazed interior is unusual for East Greek semi-closed vessels, but the clay precludes an Attic origin.
Bibliographic references: Edgar 1898/1899 / Excavations at Naukratis. B: The Inscribed and Painted Pottery (no. 44)
Bernand 1970 / Le Delta égyptien d'après les textes grecs, i: les confins libyques (p. 699, no. 566)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GA.0754) (Phase 1)
